Topic.Title: Topping?

Message.Msg: That certainly has been working for Boeing lately and given the strong fundamental case for buying it (stock buybacks, cost cutting, duopoly with relatively dysfunctional competition, 787 working, huge backlog) I probably should. I picked up the technique of waiting for stocks to break out of their trading range and then buying (or selling if it goes the other way) from books by Jesse Livermore and Nicolas Darvas and it has worked well for me so far. It is a more conservative system that does leave money on the table but has kept me from some serious losses in 2000 and 2008. Being somewhat risk adverse it works better for me. I am almost done accumulating Boeing since it is starting to get closer to fair value. My guess is that it will exceed that since it is on the Hedge / Mutual Fund radar now but I'll let the speculators play that game.

Topic.Title: MTorres floor drilling system drilling floor panels at 3-4 times faster than before use

Message.Msg: Uhh automated floor panel drililng and automated riveters similar to the ones shown at the torres site have been in use by boeing for decades. So why do you think those two types ( riveter and driling ) will make a 25 percent production flow time when compared to the previous 4 to 5 decades development and use at Boeing and elsewhere ? For example in the 60's - BA used a picture frame- panel method for wing panels using a combination squeeze-vibrate method for headless rivets ( slugs ) built by Gemcor In the late 70's- Boeing used a computer ( floppy disc) driven automated floor panel drilling macine on 747-and also on 767 in the early 80's. The 747 used a track driven and hydraulic lift posts for wing panel riveters - also built by Gemcor - that drilled, inserted- squeezed slugs and then machined the slug flush. So whats new ? better drilling, use of electric morotr cam driven squeezing, etc And since the 70's, also used electromagnetic riveting- basically to opposing coils disharging a flat plate attached to a rivet die and driving the rivet in a single blow. Initially by hand held, later by machine/ computer for 767 and later wing spar assemblies. This system/concept was derived from a NASA method using a coil on a shovel handle- wired to a LARGE capacitor bank - to flatten or remove dents from saturn tank/ dome structures.

Message.Title: And Now, For Your #$%$ Moment of the Day
Message.Msg: Bachmann: I might run for president in 2016 The retiring Tea Partyer says she isn't going anywhere and is "not taking anything off the table" By Alex Seitz-Wald In her first televised interview since announcing that she’s not going to run for reelection next year, Rep. Michele Bachmann told Fox News host Sean Hannity that we haven’t seen the last of her yet. “Sometimes you can be more effective on the outside than on the inside,” she said, echoing sentiments made by other Tea Party firebrands after being pushed out of office, like Allen West. “I’m not going away, I’m not leaving Washington, I’m not leaving the national scene.” She suggested that her future plans may even include a bid for higher office, and Hannity asked her specifically about another White House run: HANNITY: Last question, think about 2016 maybe be running for president again? BACHMANN: I’m not taking anything off the table, but certainly that is not my number one item that I’m looking at right now either. I’m in the game for the long haul. Unless things change drastically for the congresswoman in the next two years, performing even as well as she did in 2012 seems out of reach, given swirling ethics questions and the fact that some conservative leaders seem to have lost patience for the outspoken Bachmann. Another possibility, of course, would be to follow in the footsteps of like-minded politicians like Sarah Palin and Allen West to Fox News .

Topic.Title: MTorres floor drilling system drilling floor panels at 3-4 times faster than before use

Message.Msg: groooan- for some reason my 40 line explantion of facts and data re riveting seemed to be posted- but then dissappeared SO I'll try again Electromagnetic Riveting- EMR is a process and description first developed and named by urs truly in 1968 on the SST program using NASA Capacitor bank/cart initially used with a coil on the end of a shovel handle used to ding out portions of Saturn Tanks on the Apollo program. With the help of a tooling designer, I made a desktop version using opposing coils and drivers to drive 1/4 inch titanium and or A-286 rivets ( actually slugs- headless rivets which are then shaved to flushn on one side When then SST folded- so did I and did not get back to Boeing until 1973 or so. Renton- by the time in 1969-70 had made a 75-100 lb hand version for use on 747 pie section on wing panels that Gemcor riveter could not reach. I'll try and post seperately an OCR version of a 1972 trade pub article on the details Around 19777-78 Boeing gave a research contract to a few UW types to develop a low voltage version ( until then - the capacitor bank used about 4000 volts ) about the same time, Boeing mostly designed and built an automated spar assembly tool for 767 using then low voltage version developed by the UW types who had then started electro -impact. The patent issue-games played puckered severl knowledgeable boeing types- including MY sst supervisor who by then was working in tooling and running the design and development of the ASAT- A lot of then patent problem went back to having used NASA equipment on loan to the SST program And as they say- the rest is history

Topic.Title: MTorres floor drilling system drilling floor panels at 3-4 times faster than before use

Message.Msg: from 1972 trade pub Assemby Engineering page 48 blanked out personal names since yapoo seems to forbid use . ." WING PANELS FASTENED BY ELECTROMAGNETIC RIVETING Two heads are formed simultaneously on a headless rivet in only 1/2000th second with electromagnetic riveting equipment recently developed by the Boeing Company's Commercial Airplane Group, Everett, Wash. Advantages of this over conventional riveting are said to include less factory noise, fewer rejects, higher productivity, less operator fatigue and cost reductions in operations where conventional manual riveting has previously been required. According to H Buf--, project manager, EMR puts manual riveting on a par with automatic machine riveting in terms of quality and speed for a substantially smaller investment in equipment. An EMR system consists of two guns, one for each side of a workpiece, that can drive a headless rivet with a single impact. An electrical coil in each gun receives power from a common source and applies up to 30,000 pounds of force to a riveting ram. Since each gun weighs about 75 pounds, they require counterbalancing with an overhead pulley system. In addition, each gun has provisions to preclude independent firing or tiring when it is not perpendicular to a workpiece. Firing occurs when a signal from a master gun discharges a capacitor bank in an electronic control unit, and simultaneously energizes the coils in mating guns. Boeing is using EMR equipment primarily in the assembly of wing panels, which cannot be riveted with expensive automatic riveters due to accessibility problems.

Topic.Title: MTorres floor drilling system drilling floor panels at 3-4 times faster than before use

Message.Msg: Boeing is using EMR equipment primarily in the assembly of wing panels, which cannot be riveted with expensive automatic riveters due to accessibility problems. But He---k ( HANK) Sch-----t, engineer in charge of EMR development, believes such equipment would be advantageous in almost any situation where riveting is necessary. Sc---concedes that, while EMR is about twice as fast as automatic machine riveting, the new process is unlikely to replace machines that drill holes feed and set rivets and also shave installed rivets. But he feels that EMR can make older hand riveting methods obsolete when quality is the prime consideration. The quality of a riveted joint is proportional to the amount the rivet expands in the hole to produce an interference fit. The interference is important to fatigue life, and when it can't be controlled, it is necessary to cold work the hole to prevent fatigue cracking. According to S8888with EMR, the interference is excellent to ensure a tight fit all around to prevent leaks with minimal metal fatigue. AS I SAID - THE AUTOMATIC RIVETING GAME IS NOT NEW Find a magazine with knowledgeable authors who do a minimumm of research search on electromagnetic riveting or EMR for but one example - No I didm not patent the process - and 10 years later another person patened part of the driver plate- reaction mass portions
